headline: Peanut Butter and Banana Dog Biscuits
description: Crisp and crunchy, these easy-to-make, rolled, cut-out dog cookies combine peanut butter, honey, and an egg with whole wheat flour and wheat germ.

video.description: Give your dog a bone! Your dog is sure to love these biscuits, made with peanut butter, banana, and honey.
video.name: Peanut Butter Banana Dog Biscuits

name: Peanut Butter and Banana Dog Biscuits
recipeIngredient: 1 egg white, lightly beaten, for brushing

recipeInstructions.text: Preheat oven to 300 degrees F (150 degrees C). Lightly grease a baking sheet.

Stir together the egg, peanut butter, banana, and honey in a medium bowl; blend thoroughly. Stir in the flour and wheat germ; mix well. Turn dough out onto a floured board and roll to 1/4 inch thick. Cut into desired shapes with a cookie cutter, place on prepared baking sheet, and brush tops with egg white.
Bake biscuits in preheated oven until dried and golden brown, about 30 minutes, depending on size. Remove from oven and cool on a wire rack.

review.reviewBody: Quick and simple recipe! Our dog loves them! I used parchment paper instead of greasing the cookie sheet. We've made them 4x and plan to share with friends.
Worked out great. I baked them a little longer (40 minutes) and turned them after 20. Dogs love them.
My Grand Puppy, Bella, absolutely loves these every time I make them!!

Used oatmeal as no wheat germ, otherwise used all of the same ingredients. Dumped the dough onto sprayed parchment paper, folded over and patted it out to a rectangle. Unfolded paper and baked. PERFECT!! Dogs loved them as do all the neighbour dogs.
Great recipe!
Very good my black lab maggie loves it

I will definitely be making these treats again. Like some of the other reviews, I added a little extra pumpkin and peanut butter. I didn't need any water and the dough was a sticky consistency. Next time I will use cookie cutters. Thanks for posting!

The Pup loved these! Didn’t use any sweetener and just eyeballed the ingredients. Don’t get too hung up on measurements and modify with what you have. Of course, my dog is not picky and anything having any resemblance to people food is snarfed down.
I've tried others, but this one is best. Peanutty and my dogs love the sweetness of the banana. Like others, I left out the honey due to the heavy banana sugar.
My dogs just love it this is my second batch for making it for them. Will keep on making for them.

I made these with oats instead of wheat germ and added some cinnamon. I had to add more flour to overcome stickiness of p-butter. I have to say my dog loves them. Of course I had a taste.... left a very pleasant after taste in my mouth although not much sweetness which is good for pooch. I might sub pumpkin next time but these were pretty good .. my puppy begs for them. I wonder if crunchy nutty p-butter might be good?
Thanks for sharing this recipe. My dog LOVES them!!
Didn’t have wheat germ so substituted with rolled oats.

Our dog loved these cookies! I had to substitute the wheat germ for oatmeal & the wheat flour for coconut flour because it's what I had, but they're good. I had a piece of one & it's not bad at all. This recipe is a keeper!
Tried this with my four dogs and it’s amazing how they suddenly turn into different dogs. Suddenly obedient, hahaha.
Easy to make and my dog loves them better than anything we buy. He literally will do ANY trick for them!
i will make it again all the dogs in my neiborhood loved it
Easy to make and love how much fun it is to make. Me and my dad made them together and had a blast.
Dogs love these.
My 3 fur babies LOVE these!
My dog loves them! Use this recipe all the time. Thanks for sharing your recipe

I’ve been making these for awhile now. My dog, a yellow lab, Loves them! I make to the recipe except I never have wheat germ so use ground flaxseed, oatmeal, oat bran or something similar in place of that. And I don’t bother with the egg wash....he’s a dog. He doesn’t care if they’re shiny.
Very easy to make. Dogs loved it!!
Even my husband likes them!!
My dog hassles me for them! I followed the mix precisely, tossing in a few slices of American cheese because dog is bonkers for it.
My dogs loved them! They were also soft enough for my neighbor's 17 year old mostly toothless dog.
They love the treats! Easy to make and safe for my fur babies.
Can't keep these made. Dogs love them.

These were a huge hit with my fur babies, and they made my whole house smell heavenly while they baked! I made the recipe as written, and although I may experiment next time with different ingredients, this is a keeper as is!

I made these for my chihuahua so I wanted them to be small so I used my smallest cutters. She’s had two and is already begging for more. Since mine were small I ended up only having them in the oven for about 20 minutes

This recipe is Scotty dog approved. I also took it to Christmas with the family, and the puppy cousins also loved these cookies! I used oatmeal instead of wheat germ, and did not roll the dough out but did drop cookies and flattened them with my fingers. I will be making these quite often for my dog.

For Christmas, I received a dog biscuit mold, and used it to make biscuits today. I rolled about a tablespoon into a little log and squished it into the mold...much easier than rolling and cutting. See my attached picture.

Great dog-approved recipe! I didn’t change anything in the recipe but I did double it because it didn’t seem like one batch would make enough. By doubling and using a bone-shaped cutter, I was able to fill 2 cookie sheets. ( you can place them close together since they don’t expand). The dough was easy to work with which is a big plus! Made them for my friend’s dogs who loved them and kept looking for more and more!

My pommerian loves these! I replaced wheatgerm with oats and it still worked. I also used Christmas themed cookie cutters and they're fabulous! The recipe is so simple and healthy! Thank you for sharing! Jane
Granddog loves these and so easy to make.

Dogs love these. I used oatmeal and chopped peanuts instead of wheat germ. I also cooked approximately 10 minutes longer for more crunch. Dogs love it. I posted the photo of our corgi sitting patiently by oven waiting!
Easy and my dog loves them. Used flaxseed as substitute for wheat germ.

I followed the recipe exactly, except I forgot the egg wash. It still turned out great and my dogs loved them!! It’s such an easy recipe with ingredients that I normally have on hand- there’s no reason to buy any dog biscuits when you can easily make your own!

My two #goldendoodles_cuties LOVED these treats. I didn't have wheat germ so (after researching online for a good substitute ) I increased the whole wheat flour to 1 1/2 cup. Everything else stayed the same except, after adding the flour, I added blueberries (these are their normal treats). I also applied doggie yogurt icing after they cooled. Lola, my 8 year old is not a fan of Bananas but she couldn't stop smelling the sheet pan on the counter. Ziggy, 11 months wasn't sure at first because it was harder than his normal treats however, he soon realized these were the best combination of flavors!!

Made these for training my puppy. Used oat bran in place of whole wheat flour. Didn't want to throw out the yolk of one egg so threw that in the recipe. Too sticky to roll out so did tablespoon balls pressed down. Still chewy which my dog loved. Cooled them down fast, tore them up and then froze them flat. Great for training!! I ate one … tasted like peanut butter banana bread!

great recipe as is or with a bit of tweaking. I doubled the recipe and used oatmeal instead of the wheat germ. I also added flax seed for the nutritional boost. My dogs went nuts. 

I added flour or oatmeal as needed to firm up the dough and dusted flour on cutters, they cut beautifully. Made extra for neighborhood dogs

These were instantly snapped up! I made them for a dog obedience training school open house. I increased the peanut butter to 1/2 cup and subbed flax meal for the wheat germ. I also used ripe bananas that I had previously frozen, so was glad to find another use for them. The dough was a perfect consistency to roll out.

I used what I had on hand: regular unbleached flour and regular oatmeal (instead of the wheat germ).
I did not brush the tops with egg white (the dogs don't care if it's shiny!).
I used a whole banana rather than measuring a 1/2 cup.
I added extra flour before trying to roll it out because it was too sticky. (probably from the extra banana).
I used a pizza cutter to cut diamond shapes (long cuts one way, long cuts the other way).
I didn't grease the baking sheet (it's an old non-stick sheet).

I'll definitely make these again. The dogs like them, it's a simple recipe, and I know what the ingredients are.
I used brown rice flour instead of whole wheat you need almost double the amount though. I haven’t yet had a taster to see if they pass the yummy test, they were easy to make and look adorable!

I ran out of Dog treats this weekend and didn't want to make a trip into town. B-i-n-g-o! I found this yummy recipe I could make from what I already had in my cabinets. 

I substituted rolled oats for the wheat germ and water for the honey - all the same amounts. Twenty minutes in the oven, and B-i-n-g-o! All Recipes saved the day and made my Bella one happy pup! 

I saved myself a little time by rolling into balls with my hands and using a fork to press the dough like miniature peanut butter cookies because essentially, this is what they are! My Bella loved them! I'm already making batch number two! I would recommend doubling the recipe, especially if you have more than one dog! 

I took some photos, but this is my first time here. If I can find a way to upload... I'll share! Another day I'd like to try using some of my frozen blueberries in them. You could also use a little applesauce! Thank you! These are GREAT!

I ran out of Dog treats this weekend and didn't want to make a trip into town. B-i-n-g-o! I found this yummy recipe I could make from what I already had in my cabinets. 

I substituted rolled oats for the wheat germ and water for the honey - all the same amounts. Twenty minutes in the oven, and B-i-n-g-o! All Recipes saved the day and made my Bella one happy pup! 

I saved myself a little time by rolling into balls with my hands and using a fork to press the dough like miniature peanut butter cookies because essentially, this is what they are! My Bella loved them! I'm already making batch number two! I would recommend doubling the recipe, especially if you have more than one dog! 

I took some photos, but this is my first time here. If I can find a way to upload... I'll share! Another day I'd like to try using some of my frozen blueberries in them. You could also use a little applesauce! Thank you! These are GREAT!
Super easy to prepare with ingredients already in my cupboard and my dog LOVES them! Used quick oats because I did not have wheat germ on hand.

Ok look, HERE’s the way you do it... Double the recipe. Take a large baking pan from your restaurant supply store (sheet pan), throw a Silpat down on it, then dump the dough onto that. Use a rolling pin to smooth it out. My rolling pin and the sides of the pan work perfectly for keeping the dough uniform in depth. Cut the dough with a pizza cutter (roller), slather on the egg wash, and bake. This is SO much easier! :-)
My Irish Terrier LOVES his home baked "cookies"

Did make some changes b/c my dog is not to thrilled with pumpkin. Used peanut butter as base, 1/2 cup of oats and 1/2 tablespoon of honey. 

My babies loved them. Will be making them again. They were not that tasty to me
My dogs absolutely LOVED these treats. I am definitely going ro make these again!

Sally loved it - i did substitute buckwheat flour for the wheat flour 

Sally rarely eats any non meat treats, but loved these.

I made these for a pet rescue fundraiser so I multiplied the recipe by 10! I wanted at least 100 cookies, but ended up with 73. 

After making all that dough, I dreaded the thought of rolling it out, even though I had bought a personalized cookie cutter. So, I used a cookie scoop to measure the dough, rolled it in a ball and then used my cookie cutter to press the image into the bal. They turned out great! They are a bit big, but I still think the 30 minute bake time was fine. They are chewy, not crunchy. The important thing was that our two Dobermans liked them. I was so glad they did after all that- lol! I can see myself making this on a much smaller basis in the future. The only substitute I made was to use oatmeal instead of wheat germ. And, I think the egg wash does help to make them prettier. I will now try to post a picture :-)

My dog is a senior, so I used 1/2 c. gluten free and 1/2 c. shredded unsweetened coconut, 2T. ground flax, eliminated the honey and 1 egg. It was a little dry, so I added a small amount of water. After 30 min. of baking I turned the oven off and let them for an hour. They are crunchy and my dog love them!
Easy to make...Will make it often

I use this recipe regularly. My dogs wait by the oven door. In fact, now when they smell/hear me peeling a banana, they come running in anticipation. They love these treats. Used a cute cookie cutter and made some bags of treats for Christmas gifts.
My dogs go bananas about these biscuits! The dough can be sticky to work with, so requires a bit of extra flour, but once you get them cut and onto the sheet, they are good to go.

Really easy and quick to make. I followed the recipe exactly and they came out perfect. The egg wash made a nice glossy shell on the outside, inside was soft and chewy. My three dogs gobbled them down and begged for more!

I LOVE these for my pomeranian. These are our go to treats. When I first started making these several years ago - and I follow the recipe as is, I actually used a collection of puppy cookie cutter shapes (Bone, fire hydrant, dog house etc). My pom is only 4 pounds and found that we were still breaking them at least in half when giving to her. Now we roll them out on the parchment paper lined cookie sheet and use the pizza cutter and make them into little squares.

My dogs love these, so did my roommate, opps!! The first time I made these it did take a lot longer than 30 mins with my oven set on 300 degrees, I may have cut them thicker than 1/4" but it was over an hour before they had a "crunchy" texture. What seems to work for me is baking at 350 degrees for 45 mins. Even if some are thicker than others they all come out perfect!
My two shihtzu love these! My cockatoo does too! I follow the recipe as written and have two doggies anxiously waiting at the oven door!
My dog loved these. I will definitely make these again. I didnt have any wheat germ so I just added more whole wheat flourr and I didn't brush the tops.

HE LIKES IT!!! :D I followed the recipe EXACTLY - I purposely went out and bought whole wheat flour and wheat germ for this recipe (and I can use them in other recipes so it wouldn't have been a big loss), and my Shih Poo, Hunter, LOVED it! I wasn't sure if the banana was supposed to be ripe, so I just used the ones I bought right away. I'm so glad that I can now make my own dog treats, that are all natural and easy to make, and most importantly, that my dog LOVES! Thanks for the recipe!

This is a winner at our house!!! I had to use white all purpose flour,I don't keep wheat on hand,and rolled oats instead of wheat germ,I followed everything else,I used to much flour when rolling out so had to much on the back side,my fault.I cooked them 25 minutes then turned them over and cooked another 15 minutes,cooled on wire cooling rack.I melted a little butter and brushed the flour side with it.
Our 2 spoiled Pomeranian gobbled them down.
My yield was 22 cookies ,these were very quick and easy to make make and cheap too!!!! I will be making them many more times,thank you for sharing your recipe!!
Made exactly as written...two paws up...woof, woof!
this is horrible, my dog would not do nothing but one sniff. and walked away.
Made them - Loved them and my doggies do too. Did the suggested add in's. Thru everything in to my stand mixer, rolled them out and will definitely make them again.

I unplugged had gluten free plain flour on hand and used 1/2 cup wheat germ and 1/4 cup rolled oats, then mixed flour in until it was a dough consistency. Needless to say that my dog ‘woofs’ these ones down! Definitely a keeper for the recipe book!
I followed the recipe and made 35 small bone shapes for my small dog Zippy. Is there a way to determine how many calories for this recipe?

My dogs, as well as their friends, LOVED these! I have a senior dog whose teeth were all pulled prior to our adopting him, so I bake these for only 17 min. so they are soft enough for him to eat...and refrigerate them so they'll stay fresh. These stayed fresher longer than others I've made. Just made them 2 weeks ago, and the doggy friends are already asking for more!
May dogs love them! Thanks for sharing the receipe

My mini dachshund puppy loves them. She is very picky and will not eat dried dog food but knowing she needed something hard to keep her teeth clean I took a chance on this recipe. I made a second batch to put in the freezer!

I've made these twice now with the same result: the dough is too wet to roll. No problem; I formed little balls. My Navidad loves them! I used them to teach her to "speak", that's how enthusiastic she is about them! ;-)

My Dog has separation anxiety and I added about 350 milligrams of full spectrum CBD Hemp oil. CDB hemp Oil has no psychoactive effects (HIGH) and has amazing benefits when it come to anxiety. After a few days my pup was really progressing with the anxiety. I would suggest 1 to 2 1x1" squared treats. My pups issue is being placed in a create no matter if I'm right next to it or out of the house. This is a great recipe and she loves them.
I didn't have wheat germ, so I substituted it with flaxseed meal- it has a lot of health benefits for dogs. The treats smelled amazing while baking and my dog loved them! Success!

Please remember to check your peanut butter jar...ZYLOTOL A SUGAR SUBSTITUTE WILL KILL A DOG.... 
I am going to try rice flour since wheat is hard to digest...

Baked this recipe and followed it totally for my dog but I added CBD canna oil for his hip pain. Our furry son is 10 yrs old and starting to show his aches. He BEGS for these cookies and we’ll continue making them. Thanks for the great recipe.
My dogs LOVE these treats! I’ve made several batches and add a little oatmeal for texture. I skip the egg glaze, they don’t mind!
Mom recommended puppy approved!

I have made these dog cookies twice now. The first time I had to substitute oatmeal for the wheat germ as I didn't have any wheat germ. The next time I made these cookies I followed all the ingredients in the recipe. The dogs loved these cookies no matter which way I made them!
I didn't have wheat germ, so I used oatmeal on the advise of another viewer. My dog didn't notice the difference! She liked the biscuits.
Dogs love this. I use lots of flour when rolling out.
Substituted wheat germ for flaxseed and added a couple extra dollops of peanut butter and my dogs love them. So cute and fun.
i didnt have wheat germ, used oats. My puppy rottweiler LOVED these, and I feel much better giving her these instead of the garbage they sell at the stores.

Our dog really liked these. I didn't have any wheat germ so I added a half cup of shredded wheat, left out the honey. I also added an extra 1/2 cup of whole wheat flour as I wanted a stiffer dough. I baked them for 30 minutes, turned the oven off and left then in there until the oven had cooled. Our Annie always loves her cookies but she begs for these. Great recipe, thanks Sandra.
These are good for your dog, but it's a good idea to always use oats instead of flour. Dogs have trouble digesting flour, even whole wheat flour.
My dog loves them! I think they taste pretty good too. I replaced the wheat germ with flour . They didnt need 30 minuets to cook though, I took them out after 24.
No changes and loved by all the dogs at the park
Perfect as is! My dogs and colleagues dogs all loved their cookies. And the best part is they were so easy to bake.

We have 3 dogs plus do rescue and foster, these barely had time to cool before I had pups at my heels with noses in the air. A few of ours have GI issues so I skipped the wheat germ/wheat flour and used garbanzo bean flour and white rice flour and cooked at 350. I like my dogs to have crunchy bits to clean their teeth better so left them in the over after turning the heat off... Make sure they are completely dry before storing them as they can mold with any moisture left in them.

My Aussies loved this! I took the advice of other reviewers and stored mine in the fridge and my dogs liked them cold. I like the fact that the recipe is simple and uses ingredients I usually have in the house. I only changed the wheat germ to flaxseed meal and they still gobbled them up. I didn't use the egg white wash tho; didn't want to "waste" a yolk and the dogs don't care what the biscuits look like :-)

I replaced the wheat germ for 1 cup of Flaxseed Meal. Also I doubled the recipe and ended up with about 36+ cookies. My dogs loved them and I must say they were very addictive, had to hold myself back from eating them all! Haha! :-P

We are making these doggie biscuits for the second time in two weeks. However, this time we are doubling the recipe so we don't' run out so soon. Our fury kids love loved these treats. The first time we followed the recipe to a "T". This time I replaced the wheat germ with flaxseed meal just for added health benefits. We cut the biscuits in to the shape of little hearts. We're giving little gift bags of these treats to our friends with furry kids for Valentine's day?
Good basic recipe- it gives you so many ideas of what else to add in- pumpkin, sweet potato (both good for their digestion), oatmeal, etc!
Gumbo and Breeze are crazy for these biscuits. I tasted them and they are good. Not too hard. I left them in the oven after turning it off for a few more hours. Came out perfect.
Awesome doggy cookies, My dogs love them!!
I made these exactly as directed and my Shiranian and I both love them!
Made as directed except I substituted oatmeal for wheat germ. Didn't bother with the egg white and the dog doesn't seem to care LOL
My big dogs love these! I used oats instead of wheat germ and next time I will bake them longer to get them more crunchy (maybe the wheat germ helps with this? Idk). What an easy and quick recipe!

This is a FANTASTIC recipe for you and your furbaby. I made a few changes like, skipped out on the wheat germ (due to one or two of our 3 dogs is allergic to wheat), no substitutions for it. I also used a different flour, instead of the whole wheat, I used a self rising. This made the treat moist, almost like a bread. But next time I am going to cut back on the amount of bannana I use because it over powers the peanut butter. Either way, great recipe and should be used frequently. :)

item.name: Peanut Butter and Banana Dog Biscuits
